Milan|Milan]], on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] from {{English football updater|Chelsea}} club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], and the [[France national football team|France national team]]. He plays as a [[defensive midfielder]] due to his ability to break up play, but is considered to have all-round ability, as well as possessing physical power and athleticism, with France manager [[Didier Deschamps]] describing him as "a complete midfielder." After suffering a broken leg as a young player, Bakayoko joined the academy at [[Rennes F.C.|Rennes]] at the age of 13. At 14, he was turned down by the [[Clairefontaine (football)|Clairfontaine]] academy. His senior career began at Rennes where he made 24 appearances before moving to [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]] in 2014 for £7 million. In his first two seasons at the club, Bakayoko made 31 Ligue 1 appearances, but was a regular starter in the [[2016–17 Ligue 1|2016–17 season]], contributing to Monaco's Ligue 1 title win as well as being named in the [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League|2016–17 UEFA Champions League squad of the season]]. In 2017, he joined Chelsea for £40 million. Bakayoko made his first senior international appearance for France in March 2017. ==Early life== Bakayoko was born in Paris on 17 August 1994 and played for Paris 15sème O at the age of five. Aged nine, he played for CA Paris Charenton before moving to Montrogue FC 92. As a young player, Bakayoko suffered a broken leg which stopped him playing football for eight months. In 2008, at the age of 13, he joined the academy at Rennes.{{cite web|last1=Holyman|first1=Ian|title=Makelele made Chelsea target Bakayoko|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/blog/transfer-talk/79/post/3032516/tiemoue-bakayoko-chelsea-and-manchester-united-target-influenced-by-claude-makelele-and-yaya-toure|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=27 June 2017}} At 14, he was rejected by the renowned Clairefontaine academy. ==Club career== ===Rennes=== Bakayoko made his debut for the [[Ligue 1]] side on 24 August 2013 in a Ligue 1 match against [[Évian Thonon Gaillard F.C.|Évian TG]], playing the whole match in a 2–1 away win.{{cite web|last1=Pandey|first1=Kaustubh|title=Scout Report: Tiemoue Bakayoko {{!}} Monaco's midfield engine|url=http://outsideoftheboot.com/2017/03/02/scout-report-tiemoue-bakayoko-monaco/|website=Outside of the Boot|accessdate=27 June 2017|date=2 March 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2013/08/24/france/ligue-1/football-croix-de-savoie-74/stade-rennais-fc/1479069/|title=Evian vs. Rennes – 24 August 2013 |publisher=Soccerway|accessdate=18 December 2016}} ===Monaco=== ====2014–2016==== [[File:Monaco-Zenit (4).jpg|thumb|upright|Bakayoko playing for [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]] in 2014]] Bakayoko joined [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]] in July 2014 for £7 million,{{cite web|title=Tiémoué Bakayoko signs for AS Monaco on a five-year deal|url=http://www.asmonaco.com/en/article/tiemoue-bakayoko-signs-for-as-monaco-on-a-five-year-deal-65340.html|publisher=AS Monaco FC|accessdate=18 July 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170825062311/http://www.asmonaco.com/en/article/tiemoue-bakayoko-signs-for-as-monaco-on-a-five-year-deal-65340.html|archive-date=25 August 2017|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} and made his debut for the club on 10 August 2014 in a [[Ligue 1]] match against [[FC Lorient|Lorient]]. He was replaced by [[Valère Germain]] after 32 minutes in a 2–1 home loss.{{cite web|last1=Butler|first1=Michael|title=Monaco v Lorient: Ligue 1 – as it happened|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2014/aug/10/monaco-v-lorient-ligue-1-live-mbm?page=with:block-53e7c419e4b060867783c157|website=The Guardian|accessdate=27 June 2017|date=10 August 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2014/08/10/france/ligue-1/association-sportive-monaco-fc/football-cub-lorient-bretagne-sud/1686691/|title=Monaco vs. Lorient – 10 August 2014 |publisher=Soccerway|accessdate=18 December 2016}} His early substitution by Monaco manager [[Leonardo Jardim]] created a strained relationship between the two, with Bakayoko saying: "From then on, something was a little broken between him and me". After his debut, Bakayoko didn't start another match for over two months, with the remainder of his season blighted by injuries and inconsistent form.{{cite web|last1=Doyle|first1=Paul|title=Tiemoué Bakayoko: a deft midfield monster who could become a superstar at Chelsea|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/jul/17/tiemoue-bakayoko-chelsea-midfielder-monaco-claude-makelele|website=The Guardian|accessdate=18 July 2017|date=17 July 2017}} Difficulties between Jardim continued, with Bakayoko feeling unfairly treated by his manager who had become frustrated at Bakayoko's progress, questioned his attitude during training and was critical of Bakayoko for sometimes being late for meetings. ====2016–2017==== {{Quote box| width=25% |align=right |quote="Makelele helped me greatly. When he arrived at Monaco I wasn't a very, very good player, but I had a lot of discussions with him. He gave me a lot of advice and he allowed me to play my style of football more simply." |source=– Bakayoko on the advice he received from [[Claude Makelele]]}} Following his first two seasons at Monaco, in which he made 31 Ligue 1 performances, Bakayoko decided to change his behaviour to fulfil his potential, which included moving from a luxury villa to an apartment and changing the colour of his car from pink to black. Additionally, he began boxing, changed his diet and improved his strength. He was helped by former France international [[Claude Makelele]], who had been appointed director of football at Monaco in 2016,{{cite web|last1=Charles|first1=Andy|title=Claude Makelele named Monaco's new technical director|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11816/10122017/claude-makelele-named-monacos-new-technical-director|website=Sky Sports|accessdate=28 June 2017|language=en}} on how to improve his football and take care of himself off the pitch. Bakayoko also sought advice from his former youth coach at Rennes, Yannick Menu. As a result, and with [[Jérémy Toulalan]] and [[Mario Pašalić]] having both left the club in 2016, Bakayoko became a regular starter for Monaco, helping the club to the Ligue 1 title in the 2016–17 season and named in the 2016–17 UEFA Champions League squad of the season. It was a decisive season for Bakayoko. Not only had he established himself as an important part of Monaco's team with consistent performances, he had fewer injuries and his application during training was no longer criticised. During the [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League knockout phase|2016–17 UEFA Champions League round of 16-second leg match]] at the [[Stade Louis II]] on 15 March 2017, Bakayoko scored the final goal (it was his first ever [[UEFA Europa League]] or [[UEFA Champions League]] goal) with a header from a [[Thomas Lemar]] free-kick to help Monaco secure a vital goal against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]]. Monaco won 3–1 and won the tie on the away goals rule (aggregate score 6–6).{{cite web|last1=Shamoon|first1=Hafez|title=Monaco 3–1 Manchester City (agg 6–6): Monaco win on away goals|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39248906|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=9 November 2017}} During an interview, Bakayoko said a recurrence of an knee injury from 2015 leading to a crack in the [[Meniscus (anatomy)|meniscus]] caused him a lot of discomfort during his final season at Monaco: "People don't know but throughout the whole of last season I suffered because of my knee. I really had to grit my teeth in every match."{{cite web|last1=McLeman|first1=Neil|title=Chelsea's Tiemoue Bakayoko lays bare injury woe|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/chelseas-tiemoue-bakayoko-lays-bare-11046017|website=Daily Mirror|accessdate=20 May 2018|date=24 August 2017}} ===Chelsea=== [[File:Chelsea 4 five-year contract for a fee around the margin of £40 million,{{Cite news |title=Bakayoko is a Blue |url=https://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2017/07/bakayoko-is-a-blue.html |publisher=Chelsea 2017}} making him the club's second most expensive signing at the time, after [[Fernando Torres]].{{cite web|last1=Thomas|first1=Lyall|title=Tiemoue Bakayoko seals £40m Chelsea transfer from Monaco|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11668/10949875/tiemoue-bakayoko-completes-40m-chelsea-move-from-monaco|website=Sky Sports|accessdate=22 July 2017|language=en}} He made his Chelsea debut in a 2–1 away win over [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] in the Premier League on 20 August 2017.{{cite web|last1=Spencer|first1=Jonathan|title=Chelsea manager Antonio Conte praised the "commitment" of his team in a "moment that is not easy" as they bounced back from their opening-day loss to Burnley by beating Tottenham at Wembley|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40914668|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=9 November 2017}} On 5 February, he was sent off for the first time in his Chelsea career, in a 4–1 loss away to [[Watford FC|Watford]]. Bakayoko was given his marching orders for two bookable offences, one on [[Étienne Capoue]] and the other on [[Richarlison]], both in the first half.{{cite web|last1=Banks|first1=Tony|title=Watford 4 – Chelsea 1: Conte on the brink, Bakayoko red card, Deeney swears at fans|url=https://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/914889/Watford-vs-Chelsea-Conte-sack-Bakayoko-red-card-Deeney-swears-fans|publisher=Daily Express|date=6 February 2018}} Bakayoko failed to impress in his first season. He was criticised for his performances by fans and pundits alike, with games against both [[Watford F.C.|Watford]], where he was sent off after only 30 minutes, and a 3–0 away defeat by [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on the last day of the Premier League season being singled out as two of his worst.{{cite web|last1=Slagle |first1=Joel |url=https://www.footballparadise.com/tiemoue-bakayoko-anatomy/ |title=Tiémoué Bakayoko – The Anatomy of a Failed Signing |date=4 April 2018 |accessdate=14 May 2018 |publisher=Football Paradise}}{{cite web|last1=Mokbel |first1=Sami |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-5355275/Chelsea-fans-turn-Bakayoko-red-card-Watford.html |title='You’re f****** s***!' tempo reale|access-date=2018-12-02|language=en}} ==International career== Bakayoko was called up to the senior France squad for the first time to face [[Luxembourg national football team|Luxembourg]] and Spain in March 2017 after [[Paul Pogba]] withdrew through injury.{{cite news|title=Le Monégasque Bakayoko remplace Pogba chez les Bleus|url=http://sport24.lefigaro.fr/football/equipe-de-france/fil-info/le-monegasque-bakayoko-remplace-pogba-chez-les-bleus-850887|accessdate=18 March 2017|publisher=sport24.com|date=18 March 2017|language=French}} He made his debut on 28 March 2017 against the latter, replacing [[Adrien Rabiot]] at half-time of a 2–0 friendly home loss.{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2017/03/28/world/friendlies/france/spain/2381549/|title=France vs. Spain – 28 March 2017 |publisher=Soccerway|accessdate=28 March 2017}}{{cite compared to [[Yaya Touré]] due to his strong all-round qualities of pace, intelligent reading of the game, ability to intercept passes and accomplished tackling, passing and dribbling,{{cite web|last1=Yokhin|first1=Michael|title=Tiemoue Bakayoko: Meet Monaco's midfield general being squabbled over by Manchester United and Chelsea|url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/tiemoue-bakayoko-meet-monacos-midfield-general-being-squabbled-over-manchester-united-and|website=FourFourTwo|accessdate=27 June 2017|date=24 January 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Kelly|first1=Ciaran|title=Monaco star could be as crucial to Manchester United as Antoine Griezmann|url=https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/manchester-united-transfer-news-bakayoko-12808194|website=Manchester Evening News |accessdate=27 June 2017|date=29 March 2017}} as well as being physically powerful and athletic. He plays as a defensive midfielder in the [[Midfielder#Central midfielder|centre]] of the pitch, breaking up attacks and making driving forward runs, with only [[Gabi (footballer)|Gabi]] and [[Danny Drinkwater]] breaking up more attacks during the [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League|2016–17 Champions League]].{{cite web|last1=Gordon|first1=Jamie|title=Who is Tiemoue Bakayoko? £35million Chelsea target set to replace Nemanja Matic|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/football/2569337/tiemoue-bakayoko-monaco-midfielder-chelsea/|website=The Sun|accessdate=27 June 2017|date=23 June 2017}} Bakayoko's manager at Monaco, [[Leonardo Jardim]], said: "He wins a lot of balls, brings balance to the team. He passes the ball well and wins his duels. That is Bakayoko's role."{{cite web|last1=Bhardwaj|first1=Vaishali|title=Bakayoko scouting report: How he will fit in to Chelsea's midfield|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/tiemoue-bakayoko-chelsea-scouting-report-how-will-he-fit-in-to-midfield-a3575386.html|website=London Evening Standard|accessdate=18 July 2017|date=29 June 2017}} France manager [[Didier Deschamps]] described Bakayoko as "a complete midfielder", and said: "He has an important athletic presence, he's good at recovery, he scores decisive goals and is able to project himself."{{cite web|last1=Surlis|first1=Pat|title=Tiemoue Bakayoko's rise with Monaco and Chelsea role examined|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11096/10930291/tiemoue-bakayokos-rise-with-monaco-and-potential-chelsea-role-examined|website=Sky Sports|accessdate=18 July 2017|language=en}} ==Personal life== Bakayoko is of Ivorian descent, and was approached by the [[Ivory Coast national football team|national team]] before he chose France in 2017.{{cite web|url=http://rmcsport.bfmtv.com/football/la-france-ou-la-cote-d-ivoire-bakayoko-a-hesite-jusqu-au-dernier-moment-selonson-frere-1130623.html|title=La France ou la Côte d'Ivoire ?
